subject: Philosophy
title: Appeal to Authority
description: A short lesson to help you apply Appeal to Authority.

hook.text: A celebrity endorses a vitamin. Does that make it effective? Only if the celebrity is a biochemist.

buildup.text: Appeal to authority uses someone's status rather than evidence to support a claim.

discovery.text: Authorities can be wrong. Experts disagree. And expertise in one field doesn't transfer to another.

twist.text: But dismissing all experts is equally fallacious. The fallacy is blind deference, not respect for expertise.

climax.text: Good reasoning uses expert opinion as evidence â€” not as proof. The argument still needs to stand on its own.

punchline.text: Who said it matters less than why it's true.

quiz.question: When is appeal to authority a fallacy?
options: When someone's status is used as proof instead of evidence
